Sharma a ⁎ a Renewable energy and Biofuels Research Laboratory, Department of Chemistry, Indian Institute of Technology (BHU) Varanasi, Varanasi 221005, India Renewable energy and Biofuels Research Laboratory, Department of Chemistry Indian Institute of Technology (BHU) Varanasi Varanasi 221005 India aRenewable energy and Biofuels Research Laboratory, Department of Chemistry, Indian Institute of Technology (BHU) Varanasi, Varanasi 221005, India ⁎ Corresponding author. This work reports the reactivity of Mg containing spinels like MgCr2O4 and MgV2O4 for synthesis of glycerol carbonate from bio-glycerol on the basis of their structural, morphological and catalytic properties. Metal oxides having spinel structure exhibit very amazing catalytic properties due to their unique crystal structure and multiple properties like extended surface area, higher basic strength and multiple redox centres. Several characterization techniques like XRD, XPS, TGA, Raman, N2 adsorption-desorption and SEM-EDX study confirmed the successful synthesis of spinels. Amongst MgCr2O4 (MCO) and MgV2O4(MVO), MCO proved to be very active and contributed excellent catalytic activity towards glycerol valorisation i.e. 98% conversion of glycerol at mild reaction conditions than that of MVO (82% conversion of glycerol). MCO was highly efficient than that of MVO because of its higher basicity, higher crystallite size which are the fundamental properties for enhancing the catalytic activity of heterogeneous catalysts. From environmental point of view MCO was very flexible, efficient and environmentally friendly catalyst as having ideal E-factor, PMI, and AE values. Overall description concluded that the metal oxide spinels are quite active and enormously applied in glycerol biorefinery in lab scale as well as industrial scale. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Glycerol carbonate Transesterification MCO Mvo spinels Green metrics Bio glycerol 1 Introduction The rapid growth of population and technological development worldwide leads to continuous increase of energy demand. In order to fulfil the energy demand now-a- days biodiesel industries were developed in large scale. The production of biodiesel as an alternative to fossil fuel results in generation of crude glycerol (approximately 10 wt%) which remains as a glut in market [1–4]. The surplus glycerol mainly hampers the market competitiveness of biodiesel industries. Considering all these issues recent research attention is directed towards the sustainable and economical conversion of crude glycerol to various value-added products [5–9]. Glycerol can be valorised to several chemicals like acrolein, propane diols, solketals, dihydroxy acetone, lactic acid, glyceric acid, hydrogen, glycerol carbonate etc., by utilization of process technologies like esterification, oxidation, hydrogenolysis, transesterification, etherification, and reforming [10]. Amongst all the derivative of glycerol , glycerol carbonate is quite attractive product due to its outstanding physicochemical properties like low-flammability, water solubility, high biodegradability [11–15]. Glycerol carbonate has been widely used as protic solvent in plastics, resins, elastomers, surfactant, adhesive, paint, electrolyte, ink, and membrane in lithium-ion battery. . It is also broadly applied in electrochemistry field and paints as it is green and highly polar solvent [16–19]. Traditionally It was synthesized from glycerol by several process such as reaction with phosgene, reaction with urea, carbonylation with CO2 and CO but now- a-days all these processes are antiquated due to high toxicity, limitation of interaction with substrate, thermodynamic and kinetic instability of reaction process [20–23]. The reaction of glycerol with urea requires continuous removal of ammonia during reaction process. Similarly, the corrosive and toxicity nature of phosgene makes the reaction process not environmental friendly and hampers the reaction efficacy by forming undesirables isocyanic acid and biuret as side product [20–26]. Although the reaction of glycerol with CO2 under supercritical condition is a good paradigm for glycerol carbonate due to high atom utilization efficiency, low-cost raw materials but however such carbonylation is abandoned because of its thermodynamic disadvantages and very low product yield [27]. Considering all these issues one of the promising alternative pathways i.e., transesterification of glycerol with dimethyl carbonate was adopted recently which can easily boost the glycerol carbonate production process at mild reaction condition. Transesterification of glycerol with DMC is operated in presence of base catalyst and number of base catalysts including alkali and alkaline metal hydroxides, carbonates, metal oxides, hydrotalcites are reported [28–29]. Homogeneous base catalyst having high turnover frequency (TOF) value and excellent activity but the catalyst separation process and neutralization issues depreciate the use of such catalyst in glycerol transesterification. Literature revealed many heterogeneous catalyst are employed in this pathway as it is easily recovered and recycled in reaction process with excellent activity [27]. Heterogeneous catalyst also promotes the reaction process by enhancing the yield and selectivity of required products. For example, many solid base catalyst like KNO3/CaO [30], Li/ZnO [31], KF-modified hydroxyapatite [32], NaAlO2 [29], Li/ZrO2 [33], ZnO/La2O3 [34] have been employed for glycerol carbonate synthesis however they exhibit several issues such as high reaction temperature, poor reusability, excess solvent requirement, high DMC to glycerol molar ratio, less stability and recyclability of catalyst. As a result, a new strategy is explored for obtaining higher activity and stability at moderate reaction condition for production of glycerol carbonate [35–36]. Till date magnesium based many heterogeneous catalysts like MgO/Al2O3 [36] LiNO3/Mg4AlO5.5 [37], Mg/Al/Zr [38], Mg/Zr/Sr [39], MgO/La2O3 [40] were applied in glycerol carbonate synthesis . All these catalysts provided 75–99% glycerol conversion with in the temperature range 75–100 °C. If we consider the active basic sites of alkaline earth metal oxides on the basis of effect of CO2 adsorption, that follows the order as MgO > CaO > SrO > BaO and the order of basic strength is about MgO < CaO < SrO < BaO . However, it was interesting and challenging to incorporate magnesium with transition metals like vanadium oxide, chromium oxide in order to enhances the stability, catalytic activity and basic strength of MgO. In this work we have designed magnesium based solid base catalyst like MgV2O4, MgCr2O4 and applied in transesterification of glycerol. Herein, we also discussed the comparative study of catalytic activity of all the synthesized catalyst. To the best of our knowledge these catalysts are first time applied in glycerol carbonate synthesis and such type of comparative study of all these synthesized catalysts is not reported anywhere. Here we have also attempted to explore the role of effect of transition metals like Cr and V on the activity of magnesium metal in glycerol transesterification. In this work we prepared a series of magnesium based transition metal oxide (Cr,V,) catalyst by co-precipitation route and used in glycerol carbonate synthesis. Each reaction was individually observed, over all these catalyst and conversion percentage of glycerol was also well studied. The relationship between conversion of reactant species, selectivity and yield percentage of product, acidic and basic properties were systematically analysed. Many characterization techniques like XRD, TGA-DSC, FE-SEM, Raman Spectra, BET-Surface area, XPS spectra were performed to identify the physicochemical properties of designed catalyst and their effect on catalytic performance. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials required Magnesium nitrate hexa hydrate Mg(NO3)26H2O, Chromium nitrate nonahydrate Cr(NO3)3•9H2O, Vanadyl nitrate VO(NO3)3, ammonium hydroxide solution (25% water), glycerol, dimethyl carbonate, methanol etc. were procured from Merck Pvt.Ltd, which are of analytical grade(AR). All the chemicals having 99% purity used in chemical analysis without further purification. 2.2 Catalyst preparation technique The mixed oxides of magnesium with different transition metals like MgCr2O4, MgV2O4, were synthesized via co-precipitation route at constant pH range 8–10 using metal nitrate as precursors. First of all, required amount of magnesium nitrate was taken in a beaker and dissolved in specific amount of de-ionised water. In another beaker specific amount of chromium nitrate was taken and dissolved with distilled water. Both the solutions were mixed with each other and undergoes stirring at 40 °C (Mg: Cr molar ratio equal to 1:2 in the reaction mixture). During the reaction process there was dropwise addition of ammonia solution (ammonium hydroxide) in order to maintain the pH 8–10 as well as to form precipitation. After the formation of precipitate the reaction mixture was also stirred for another 5 h to enhance the selective growth of precipitate phase. Then the product mixture was filtered, washed with hot water several times in order to remove any impurities. After that the solid sample was kept in oven at 110 °C for overnight and then calcined at 900 °C for 4 h in a muffle furnace. Finally, the resultant product was collected from the furnace, crushed and sieved to get the fine powder form of catalyst. The obtained catalyst was stored and further used in transesterification of glycerol. In this similar way other catalyst like MgV2O4, was also synthesized and tested in transesterification of glycerol. 2.3 Characterization of synthesized catalysts The thermal stability of synthesized catalyst like MgCr2O4, MgV2O4 were analysed by TGA technique using Mettler Toledo 1* instrument maintaining the temperature range 50–1000 °C with heating rate 10 °C min−1. The crystalline nature of prepared catalysts was analysed by powder X-ray diffractometer (Rigaku Miniflex 300/600) with Cu Kα radiation at 45 kV and 40 mA.The surface morphology and elemental composition of synthesized catalyst were detected through field emission scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM) NOVA Nano SEM 450 equipped with EDAX-Ametek detector. The surface area, pore volume, pore diameter of all the catalysts were studied through N2 physisorption analyser with Quanta chrome Autosorp-1C instrument and Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method at −196 °C. The basic strength of synthesized catalysts was analysed by Hammett Indicators method using phenolphthalein (H- = 9.3), 2,4- dinitroaniline (H- 15.0), 4- nitroaniline (H-= 18.4), and aniline (H- = 27.0). The surface properties and oxidation state of metal atoms present in synthesized catalysts were investigated by ESCA X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) equipped with aluminium monochromator source (Al kα radiation) having energy 1486.7 eV operated at 15 kV and 20 mA. The stretching and bending frequency of synthesized catalysts were studied through Raman spectra using Renishaw In-Via Raman microscope. 2.4 Catalytic activity test The activity of all the prepared catalysts were tested in transesterification of glycerol-to-glycerol carbonate by simple reflux condensation process. The reaction was carried out in a 100 mL round bottom flask taking 54 mmol of glycerol (5 g) 162 mmol of DMC (14.6 g) followed by addition of catalysts like MgCr2O4, MgV2O4 separately varying the weight percentage from 1 to 10 wt.% each according to the weight of glycerol used. Subsequently the reaction mixture was heated to attain the optimum temperature for an optimum time with continuous stirring. The advancement of the reaction process was monitored by gas chromatography. After the completion of reaction process the product mixture was filtered for easy separation of catalyst and further study in next reaction process. The remaining DMC and methanol present in liquid mixture was also separated using rotary evaporator. The product was detected using gas chromatography (Agilent technology 7890B) equipped with flame ionization detector and capillary column HP-5 (30 m × 0.32 mm × 0.25 mm). Tertiary butanol was used as internal standard for quantification analysis. The conversion and yield percentage of glycerol and glycerol carbonate were calculated using the following equations, similarly the turnover frequency (TOF) was also calculated as (1) G l y c e r o l C o n v e r s i o n ( % ) = N o o f m o l e s o f g l y c e r o l r e a c t e d T o t a l n o o f m o l e s o f g l y c e r o l t a k e n × 100 (2) S e l e c t i v i t y ( % ) = N o o f m o l e s o f d e s i r e d p r o d u c t T o t a l n o o f m o l e s o f a l l p r o d u c t s × 100 (3) Y i e l d ( % ) % glycerol conv × % GLC selectivity 100 (4) T O F = m g l y c e r o l X g l y c e r o l M g l y c e r o l 100 m c a t a l y s t t Where m glycerol stands for initial amount of glycerol (moles), X glycerol is the conversion of glycerol, Mglycerol refers to molecular weight of glycerol, m catalyst is the amount of catalyst (mass) used in transesterification reaction and t stands for time of reaction. It was observed the conversion of glycerol was higher by using MCO catalyst than that of MVO catalyst in same reaction condition. Similarly, the turn over frequency (TOF) values for the synthesized catalysts were measured and presented in Table 1 . The TOF of, MgCr2O4, and MgV2O4 are 6.38, and 5.23 h−1 respectively. The obtained TOF values are mostly comparable to TOF value of 0.5–11 h−1 using catalysts like MgO, MgO-ZrO2, and MgO-ZrO2-SrO2 reported by Parameswaram et al. [39]. Transesterification of ethylene carbonate using ionic liquid reported by xu et al. has the TOF value of 0.96 h−1 [41]. Similarly, Sharma et al. reported TOF value for NiMgOx heterogeneous catalyst in transesterification of glycerol is 7.13–7.98h−1 [42]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 TGA The thermal stability of synthesized spinels MCO and MVO were studied by thermogravimetric analysis under inert atmosphere. TGA plot of uncalcined MCO depicted in Fig. 1(a) . It showed three step of mass decomposition with rise in temperature. The 1st phase of weight loss happened around 100–220 °C that might be due to evaporation of surface adsorbed water molecules. The 2nd phase of mass loss occurred around 320–475 °C which could be due to release of crystal water, loss of capping agents or any organic moieties present in designed catalyst. From the graph it was revealed that the 3rd stage of mass loss started around 490 °C which is ascribed to disintegration of nitrate or carbonate species present in synthesized catalyst. The constant weight was reached around 800 °C indicating the stable temperature of MCO spinel i.e., minimum calcination temperature required for complete formation of MgCr2O4 catalyst. Similarly, TGA curve of MgV2O4 (MVO) is depicted in Fig. 1(b). In case of MVO, we obtained four phases of mass loss with subsequent rise in temperature. The first phase of mass loss was taken place around 100- 210 °C which was attributed to evaporation of surface water molecules. The 2nd phase of mass loss of the sample at 260–380 °C which ascribed to removal of chemically adsorbed water molecules. The next phase (3rd) of weight loss happened at 530 °C which might be due to removal of any organic or inorganic impurities. Around 600 −800 °C it seems that there was also another phase of mass loss taken place which might be due to decomposition of nitrate or any other moieties and complete formation of mixed oxide. After 850 °C the compound becomes stable indicating the appropriate calcination temperature of synthesized MVO. 3.2 XRD X-ray diffraction pattern being one of the reliable techniques for determination of crystalline structure, crystal orientation, crystallite size and phase of the compound were studied for both two synthesized catalysts. Fig 2(a) revealed the XRD pattern of MCO catalyst. It is seen that all the samples are cubic spinel type structure according to standard pattern of JCPDS file .The diffraction peaks at 2θ values 18.41°, 26.32°, 28.92°, 31.03°, 35.32°, 37. 71°, 43.40°, 46.51°, 51.43°,57. 04°, 60.08°, 63.05°,66.28°, 72.54°,75.62°,76.88°,79.64° and 87.52° can be indexed to miller indices (111), (211), (210), (222), (220), (311), (400), (420) ,(331), (422), (511), (440), (531), (620), (442), (444), (642) and (640) of crystal planes of spinel MgCr2O4 which matched with JCPDS No-100,351 respectively. There was no other peaks in X-ray diffractogram of compound suggesting that single phase of MgCr2O4 crystal was formed and the very sharp and intensive peaks of MgCr2O4 confirmed the well crystallized structure of catalyst [43–45]. Using Scherrer's equation from the diffraction peak (220) the crystallite size was calculated and found to be 34.6 nm. (6) D = 0.9 λ β c o s θ Where λ correspond to wavelength of X-ray beam, β is the line broadening at full width at half maxima, D refers to average crystallite size and θ is the Bragg angle. The lattice parameter (a) and unit cell volume of MgCr2O4 catalyst were 9.36A° and 578.4A°3 respectively. Similarly in Fig. 2(b) the major diffraction peaks at 2θ = 14.37°, 18.23°, 23.72°, 29.98°, 32.35°, 34.95°, 36.08°, 42.93°, 47.02°, 49.43°, 53.25°, 56.76°, 59.17°, 62.33°, 63.08°, 65.53°, 70.74°, 73.72°, 74.72°, 78.66°, 81.55° and 86.41° assigned to crystal planes of miller indices (100), (111), (211), (220), (310), (222), (300), (400), (331), (320), (411),(422), (511), (512), (440), (421), (531), (532), (622), (444), (551) and (642) respectively . All the diffraction patterns were consistent with JCPDS No- 772,130 indicating a single crystal face centred cubic phase of MgV2O4 . The lattice parameter was calculated to be a = b = c = 8.27A°, and unit cell volume of MgV2O4 was obtained to be 482.76A3°. The average crystallite size of spinel MgV2O4 was calculated using above Scherrer equation and obtained to be 27.84 nm. If we compare the XRD pattern of both MgCr2O4 and MgV2O4 spinel the diffraction peaks are more sharper and intensed in case of MgCr2O4 catalyst than that of MgV2O4 spinel indicating higher crystallinity in sample [46–48]. The higher crystallinity and higher lattice parameters of MgCr2O4 spinel might be one of cause of better conversion of glycerol. The structural parameters and phase composition of both the spinel is represented in Table 1. 3.3 SEM-EDX and Surface Area The surface morphology and elemental composition of synthesized MgCr2O4 and MgV2O4 spinels were analysed by SEM-EDX analyser. Fig 3(b) depicts the SEM micrographs of MgCr2O4 , it was appeared that there was homogeneous distribution of intermixed grains of variable size having some porosity . The grains are finely distributed and signifies the nano sized nature of MgCr2O4 spinel which exclusively enhanced the surface area of catalyst and highly suitable for transesterification reaction of glycerol [49,50]. From elemental compositions and characteristics peak of magnesium chromite energy line confirmed the elements like Mg, Cr and O are present with adequate amounts according to their atomic and weight percentage. Overall, EDX analysis confirmed the successful synthesis of MgCr2O4 catalyst. The SEM-EDX micrograph of MgV2O4 catalyst is shown in Fig. 3(a). It is revealed that the particles are not uniformly distributed in the microsphere of MgV2O4 catalyst. The particles possessed variable polyhedral shape of uneven size i.e. non regular dimensional shape [51,52]. The particle size of MgV2O4 spinel is larger than that magnesium chromite although it is in nano range suggesting the decrease in surface area of magnesium vanadate (MVO) microsphere. As a result, MVO has lesser activity in transesterification of glycerol than that of magnesium chromate (MCO). The elemental composition and intensity of peaks indicated in EDX histogram revealed there was successful synthesis of MVO with respect to the atomic and weight percentage of elements like Mg, V and O present in the designed catalyst. The specific surface area, pore volume and pore diameter of the synthesized both spinel MCO and MVO were determined through N2 adsorption desorption isotherm and depicted in Fig. 4. It was obtained that the specific surface area of MVO was 23.8 m2/g where as the specific surface area of MCO was 28.7 m2/g which is larger than that of MVO. Similarly, the pore size and pore volume distribution of MCO was higher as compared to that of MVO. The dimension of pores for MCO lies around 3.7- 18.6 nm where as the pore size distribution of MVO lies in the range of 2.5–11.8 nm respectively. Both the spinels having type IV hysteresis loop according to IUPAC classification and belong to mesoporous materials [45,53]. MCO having more concentrated pore size distribution and highest specific surface area facilitate the transesterification reaction of glycerol. As it is known that transesterification of glycerol in presence of heterogeneous catalyst is a surface phenomenon and catalytic activity prefers larger surface area so MCO catalyst having high surface area enhanced the conversion of glycerol than that of MVO catalyst. 3.5 XPS The surface composition, chemical state and oxidation state of synthesized both spinels MCO and MVO were investigated by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) technique. The obtained results shown in fig (5) revealed that all the elements like Mg, Cr and O are present on the surface of catalysts. In case of MCO chromium exhibits two types of oxidation state in Cr 2p region. The binding energy at 576.3 eV correspond to 2p 3/2 peak of Cr3+ species where as the binding energy at 579.0 eV assigned to 2p3/2 of Cr6+ species [54]. The peak at 588.47 eV corresponds to Cr3+ 2p1/2. All these peaks are relatively nearer to standard binding energy Cr3+ of Cr2O3 . O 1 s spectra shows two distinguished deconvoluted peaks in two different binding energy state, such as the first binding energy at 530.06 eV attributed to lattice oxygen of metal oxygen bonding where as another peak at 532.64 eV arises may be due to oxygen vacancy or absorbed oxygen species in the form of carbonates or hydroxyls [55,56]. Similarly, 1 s spectrum of Mg is depicted in Fig. 5(b). The peak at binding energy 1304 eV correspond to 1 s spectra of Mg2+ species. The phenomena of surface composition and oxidation state of elements present in MVO spinel were explored by XPS survey and depicted in fig (6). The characteristics peak at 517.3 eV assigned to 2P3/2 spectrum of Vanadium metal and the peak at 526.7 eV correspond to V 2P1/2 spectrum. The difference in spin orbit coupling of core level spectrum of V 2p spectrum was mostly about 7.4 eV which confirmed vanadium exists in +3 oxidation state [57–59]. Mg 1 s shows the characteristics peak of Mg2+ at 1305.3 eV. In O 1 s spectrum the deconvoluted peaks at 529.6 eV and 532.3 eV assigned to bonded oxygen and oxygen defects in the sample respectively .The distribution of two different oxygen species can be measured by taking the ratio of [O ads]/ [O lat], higher area ratio indicates larger amount of oxygen vacancies where as lower area ratio indicates lesser oxygen vacancies [49,56]. Here the area ratio of [O ads] /[O Lat] for MCO is bigger than that of MVO, hence MCO has higher amount of surface oxygen as well as vacant oxygen than that of MVO. 3.6 Raman spectra The Raman spectra of synthesized spinel MCO and MVO were depicted in Fig. 7. Fig 7(a) revealed Raman spectra of MCO. Mainly six vibration bands at 152, 226, 446,684, 851 and 932 cm−1 were observed in Raman spectrum of MCO spinel. The vibration band at 226.5cm-1 is due to F2g mode, the band at 446cm−1 correspond to Eg mode where as the band at 684 cm-1 attributed to A1g respectively. Besides these the strong band at 684 cm−1 signifies the stretching vibrational mode of metal oxygen bond. (Tetrahedrally coordinated M-O bond). The band at 851 and 932 cm−1 assigned to vibrational mode of octahedral sublattice. The modification of Cr3+ lattice with Mg2+lattice shifted Raman stretching band at 446 cm−1 from 447 cm−1 might be one of the causes for creation of oxygen vacancy [56]. Another broad peak at 684 cm−1 might be due to O2− vacancies formed in MCO by replacement of Cr(VI) by Cr (III) [60]. The overall study of Raman spectra of MCO concluded that the incorporation of Mg to chromate lattice did not distort the crystal structure but generates oxygen vacancies in the spinel which enhanced the catalytic activity (as oxygen vacancy and number of oxygen species increased the catalytic activity) which was completely agree with XPS data of MCO. The Raman spectra of MVO spinel is illustrated in Fig. 7(b). The Raman band at 143cm−1 can be ascribed to bending vibration of -O-V-O- bond. The other peaks at 480 and 528 cm−1 correspond to stretching vibration of V-O bond. Similarly, the band at 280, 711 cm−1 assigned to bending vibration of V = O bond which were probably attributed to oxygen vacancies in MVO spinel. The peak at 404, 993 cm−1 can be assigned to Mg-O bending vibration band of MVO spinel. In case of MVO oxygen defects are easily formed at the edge of V-O site as the peak at 528 and 711 cm−1 [58,60]. 3.7 Basicity study The basic site and basicity of heterogeneous catalyst plays major role in the transesterification of glycerol, as a result it is highly required to study the basic strength and basicity of synthesized catalyst. Here we studied all the properties by simple Hammett indicator titration method and the result obtained are represented in Table 2 . The indicators like bromothymol blue (H_ =7.2), phenolphthalein (H_ = 9.8), 2,4- dinitroaniline (H_ = 15.0), 4-nitroaniline (H_ = 18.4) were used in titration method. Around 25 mg of catalyst was taken and stirred with 1.0cm3 of Hammett indicator solution diluted with methanol and kept for 2 h to equilibrate. After a certain time, there was change in colour of indicator solution implying the catalyst is stronger base than indicator. The overall basicity of synthesized catalyst was quantitatively calculated by Hammett indicator benzene carboxylic acid titration method. It was observed that pure Mg (NO3)2 possessed H_ value in the range 9.8–15.0 which was relatively weak medium basic site to catalyst. Similarly, the parent Cr(NO3)3, VO(NO3)3 were acidic by nature and did not change the colour of bromothymol blue . The basic strength of all the salts were improved by addition of MgO. It was obtained that with addition of MgO the basic strength of catalysts falls in the range of 15< H_ <18.4 which is moderate basic site for the catalyst and considered as strong base. Although the basic strength of all the three catalysts were similar but the number of basic sites (total basicity in terms of millimole /g) was highest for MgCr2O4 (MCO) in comparison to MgV2O4 (MVO) as given in Table 1. MCO having highest basic site enhanced the conversion of glycerol as transesterification follows base catalysed reaction. 3.8 Proposed reaction mechanism and green metrics study of designed catalyst A possible reaction pathway involved in transesterification of glycerol is depicted in Scheme 1 . Initially the Lewis basic site (Mg2+) of synthesized MCO catalyst abstract the acidic proton of primary hydroxyl group of glycerol with simultaneous activation of carbonyl carbon of DMC by Lewis acidic site (Cr3+). As a result, the formed glyceroxide anion undergoes nucleophilic addition with activated DMC to form hydroxyl alkyl carbonate with elimination of methanol as side product. The hydroxyl alkyl carbonate being unstable intermediate undergoes cyclization to form cyclic glycerol carbonate and regenerate the catalyst. Commonly the solid base catalyst acts as a very good support for the abstraction of H+ from glycerol by the basic site of catalyst. Higher basicity of catalyst can enhanced the more negative charge on glyceroxide anion and subsequently lower the free energy of reaction [30]. The designed MgCr2O4 having highest basicity promotes conversion of glycerol with highest glycerol carbonate yield of 95.7% . Recent time with increase in environmental awareness much more emphasis is given to waste remediation, waste prevention in order to control the pollution by end of pipe solutions. Thus, green chemistry mainly focuses on effective utilization of raw materials, elimination of toxic and hazardous reagents for the manufacture of any chemical products and acts as primary pollution prevention than waste remediation. There are several green chemistry metrics are studied by researchers like E-factor, process mass intensity (PMI), Effective mass yield (EMY) etc. for the assessment of environmental effect on manufacturing process [61,62]. Generally, in an organic synthesis catalysis acts an important role in waste elimination for the production of fine chemicals as a result various green metrics were especially high for this reaction process. The E-factor is the simple ratio of mass of waste to mass of desired product (kg waste /kg product). In order to calculate the E-factor the total yield, reagents, solvent losses and energy consumption (although it is difficult to calculate) are taken in to consideration. In transesterification of glycerol using MgCr2O4 catalysis process the total E-factor was estimated by taking glycerol, DMC,GLC,by -product methanol, catalyst mass used and produced as substrate, reagent and product. In this process by-product methanol is not considered as waste since it was easily recovered and further utilized in biodiesel production process. The obtained E-factor value for transesterification of glycerol using MgCr2O4catalysis was 0.87 < 1 . Such type of E-factor lies in the range of 0 < 0.87 < 1 confirmed the catalyst is cordial to environment. Carbon efficiency%(CE ) is the simple measure of carbon percentage present in the reagents used in organic synthesis which just reside in the final product [61,63,64]. This carbon efficiency mainly committed to evaluate the greenness of organic synthesis based on carbon accounting. Mathematically it is represented as (7) C E % = A m o u n t o f c a r b o n i n p r o d u c t T o t a l c a r b o n p r e s e n t e d i n r e a c t a n t × 100 In transesterification of glycerol with DMC in presences of MCO catalyst the percentage of carbon efficiency calculated as (8) C E % = N o o f m o l e s o f G L C × N o o f c a r b o n i n G L C * 100 M o l e s o f g l y c e r o l * N o o f c a r b o n i n g l y c e r o l + N o o f m o l e s o f D M C × N o o f c a r b o n i n D M C Using the above formula, the carbon efficiency for transesterification of glycerol was found to be 0.631 which lies in the range of 0 to 1. As the carbon efficiency lies within this range by application of MCO catalyst so the synthetic process of glycerol carbonate is greener by nature. The effective mass yield (EMY) for the transesterification process was calculated using the formula as (9) E M Y % = M a s s o f f i n a l p r o d u c t M a s s o f t o x i c r e a g e n t s × 100 Generally, this parameter estimates the percentage of final product in all reagents and materials used in organic synthesis .Reagents having very low environmental impact (NaCl,CH3COOH) are excluded from the estimation of effective mass yield .In transesterification process mostly the chemicals used like glycerol, DMC and the product GLC, methanol and the catalyst are benign by nature as they have no environmental risk as a result the effective mass yield was obtained to 100% which proved the greenness of catalytic synthesis process of glycerol carbonate. Similarly, another green metrics namely Solvent and catalyst environmental impact parameter(f) was also studied for GLC synthesis and well explained. It helps in evaluation of actual mass of materials used in the reaction process. Solvent and catalyst environmental impact parameter: (10) ( f ) = M a s s o f r e a c t i o n a n d p o s t r e a c t i o n s o l v e n t s a n d m a t e r i a l + m a s s o f c a t a l y s t u s e d M a s s o f f i n a l p r o d u c t This parameter has zero value if all the materials (substrate, solvent, catalyst etc.) used in individual or overall step of synthesis are recovered, reused or eliminated otherwise in every other case it is greater than zero. As the transesterification of glycerol using MCO catalysis follows reusability and recovery of catalyst in each step hence the f value for the entire process is zero which addressed the greenness of process. Process mass intensity (PMI) being a key metrics adopted by researcher to determine the sustainability of organic manufacturing process in many chemical reactions. This also consider reaction efficiency, stoichiometry, number of solvents, reagents and additional substances used in synthetic process. For an ideal synthesis the PMI value remain as one (1) where total mass of input reactants is equal to total mass of product. PMI can be mathematically written as (11) P M I = T o t a l m a s s u s e d i n p r o c e s s ( g ) M a s s o f f i n a l p r o d u c t ( g ) Transesterification of glycerol using MCO catalysis have the PMI value as 1.78 g−1 suggesting the greenness of process. 4 Effect of operating parameters on glycerol transesterification 4.1 Influence of reaction temperature Temperature being one of the important parameters in transesterification of glycerol was optimized and revealed in Fig. 8 (a). There was no appreciable improvement of conversion of glycerol beyond 85 °C, suggesting the decarboxylation reaction at high temperature to glycidol which further converted to polyglycerol by ring -opening polymerization [21,31]. High temperature also aggravates undesired reactions like dehydrogenation and condensation reactions of by product methanol which also reduces the activity of catalyst in conversion process of glycerol. 4.2 Influence of reaction time The effect of reaction time over transesterification of glycerol was studied and depicted in Fig. 8(b). It was revealed that the reaction achieved highest conversion of 98% with subsequent increase in reaction time from 20 min to 80 min.. The conversion and yield of glycerol and GLC decreased gradually when the time prolonged above 80 min, implying the conversion of GLC to glycidol. This type of disorder in GLC yield and glycerol conversion might be due to that the reaction reached at equilibrium within 80 min [35,37]. 4.3 Influence of DMC to glycerol molar ratio The transesterification reaction was highly affected by molar ratio of reactants and shown in Fig. 8(c). It was observed that with increase in molar ratio DMC/glycerol from 1 to 4 the conversion of glycerol reached from 56% to 98% as well as yield percentage also maximized from 48% to 95.7%. Further increase of DMC to glycerol ratio above 4:1 there was gradual decrease of conversion of glycerol that might be due to immiscibility of hydrophilic glycerol and hydrophobic DMC at high concentrations i.e., solubility effect. Another phenomenon hampers the conversion of glycerol at high DMC: glycerol molar ratio is that the rate of reaction becomes slower due to very low concentration of glycerol [23,28]. 4.4 Influence of catalyst mass The effect of catalyst amount used in glycerol transesterification reaction was investigated and depicted in Fig. 8(d). It was observed that there was steady increase of conversion of glycerol from 62% to 98% with increase in catalyst amount up to 5wt% of glycerol used in reaction process. Such type of improvement in conversion percentage of glycerol might be due to increase in overall basic site of catalyst. Further increase in catalyst amount above 5wt% did not influenced conversion of glycerol that might be due to possibility of blocking of pores and lack of availability of active sites at high mass of catalyst [24,38]. 4.5 Catalyst stability test Considering the positive effect on environment and economic factor the stability, activity and reusability of synthesized catalyst was studied and depicted in Fig. 9 . It was found that the catalyst was stable up to six cycles in transesterification of glycerol. The recyclability was investigated by leaching test. This leaching test was performed by hot filtration method as we have discussed in our previous research article [42]. In this process consecutive batch experiment were carried out and after each consecutive reaction the catalysts were regenerated by washing thoroughly with methanol and dried in oven. Fig 9 depicts the conversion percentage of glycerol and yield percentage of GLC obtained from successive regenerated catalyst. The result revealed that the catalyst is highly efficient and reusable up to six times with no appreciable decrease in activity. The phenomenon of stability of catalyst up to 6th cycle was attributed to well organized crystallite structure of its phase which helps in stabilizing the metallic species of Mg 2+ and Cr3+ as confirmed by leaching test. In order to get a concrete idea related to the stability and activity of synthesized catalyst we have also explored the physicochemical properties by XRD and SEM-EDX study and depicted in Fig. 10 . From X-ray diffraction study we obtained complete change of single phase of MCO to multiple phases of diffraction peaks after six time runs in transesterification reaction. The diffraction pattern at 2θ value 19.91°, 35.43°, 49.06° indexed to (003),(101) and (015) respectively correspond to HCrO2 having rhombohedral symmetry, matched with standard pattern of JCPDS −898,249. Similarly many other diffracted peaks of Cr (CO)6 also appeared with 2θ = 17.78°, (110), 20.58°,(201) and 36.24°(331) which were matched with standard pattern 720,049 having orthorhombic crystal symmetry. There were also some peaks of MgCO3 appeared due to trapping of atmospheric CO2 by the synthesized MCO during reaction process which also matched with JCPDS file −862,344. Many other peaks at 2θ= 34.54°, 51.78°, 68.82° with corresponding miller indices values (024), (113) and (404) ascribed to Mg6Cr2CO3(OH)16•4H2O of rhombohedral symmetry (JCPDS no- 451,475). The change in crystalline structure and appearance of multiple phases disturbs the stability and activity of single phase MCO spinel after six times run. The SEM micrograph of MCO after six time run in glycerol transesterification reaction is depicted in Fig. 10(b). It was revealed the particles are agglomerated and possessed irregular geometry due to presence of variable forms like Mg (CO)3, Cr (CO)6, HCrO2 etc. which highly deactivate the catalyst's active sites. Thus, this designed catalyst can be immensely endorsed to commercialize for industrial scale for production of glycerol carbonate. 4.6 Comparative study of catalytic activity of synthesized catalyst with other reported catalyst Many researchers have reported several heterogeneous catalysts for transesterification of glycerol using different reaction conditions which is provided in Table 3 . Catalyst like Ti-SBA-15 [65] although provided very good conversion and yield of glycerol and GLC but the time duration for highest conversion is so high. The catalytic activity of Au /Fe2O3 [66] and CaAl-LDHs [24] were also very poor towards conversion of glycerol at high reaction temperature as well as long reaction time. On the other hand, MgO/ZrO2 catalyst offered a very good conversion of glycerol (96%) with expense of long reaction time 150 min but the yield percentage towards GLC was very poor. The long reaction time and high reaction temperature are the major drawbacks of the catalyst. Another catalyst like NaAlO2 [29] with GL template have highest selectivity towards GLC (100%) however, it required prolonged reaction time. Similarly many catalyst like Li/Mg4AlO [37], Cu/La2O3 [67], KF/La-Zr [68], Li/ZrO2 [33], Zn/La [69] and Ca/La [70] have different types of drawbacks such as prolonged reaction time, high reaction temperature, poor reusability , very low conversion, yield and selectivity , high DMC to glycerol molar ratios etc. Considering all these issues related to reported catalyst we have designed and investigate the properties of a new heterogeneous MCO catalyst for better catalytic activity in transesterification of glycerol and also to conquer all the drawbacks in transesterification reaction of glycerol. The catalytic activity, stability and reusability of synthesized MCO catalyst is quite attractive and found to be comparable with other reported catalyst. 5. Conclusion In this work, a greener route was adopted for synthesis of glycerol carbonate from biowaste glycerol derived from biodiesel plant via transesterification reaction.. A comparative study between spinel like MCO and MVO for transesterification reaction was conducted. Various analysis process like XRD, SEM-EDX, RAMAN, XPS, BET -surface area, TGA revealed the complete formation of MCO and MVO framework. All these characterizations suggested that MCO possess higher basic strength, higher specific surface area, bigger lattice distortion, smaller particle size than that of MVO catalyst. All these properties of MCO were highly beneficial for conversion of glycerol. Another major reason for better conversion of glycerol using MCO that the presence of Chromium in +6 oxidation may contribute to the regulation of [O ads/ O Lat] ratio which enhanced the catalytic activity for glycerol transesterification relative to MVO. Various reaction parameters were also optimized for better yield of glycerol carbonate and also achieved at optimized condition. The greenness and sustainability of catalyst and reaction process were also checked for, whether the entire process is environmentally friendly or not. The green metrics like E-factor, PMI, AE etc. study suggested that the catalyst is advantageous and environmental benign by nature. Prime novelty statement In this work Mg based transition metal mixed oxide catalysts were investigated details on structural properties and catalytic activity for synthesis of glycerol carbonate. The application of these spinel is new in glycerol valorisation field. The results obtained reflect that the catalyst performed well for glycerol biorefinery process. Basically, MCO showed better catalytic activity and stability than that of MVO. This relationship of current catalyst may opt a useful reference in designing the catalyst for production of highly pure glycerol carbonate from biowaste glycerol. coredata.dc:description: This work reports the reactivity of Mg containing spinels like MgCr2O4 and MgV2O4 for synthesis of glycerol carbonate from bio-glycerol on the basis of their structural, morphological and catalytic properties. Metal oxides having spinel structure exhibit very amazing catalytic properties due to their unique crystal structure and multiple properties like extended surface area, higher basic strength and multiple redox centres. Several characterization techniques like XRD, XPS, TGA, Raman, N2 adsorption-desorption and SEM-EDX study confirmed the successful synthesis of spinels. Amongst MgCr2O4 (MCO) and MgV2O4(MVO), MCO proved to be very active and contributed excellent catalytic activity towards glycerol valorisation i.e. 98% conversion of glycerol at mild reaction conditions than that of MVO (82% conversion of glycerol). MCO was highly efficient than that of MVO because of its higher basicity, higher crystallite size which are the fundamental properties for enhancing the catalytic activity of heterogeneous catalysts. From environmental point of view MCO was very flexible, efficient and environmentally friendly catalyst as having ideal E-factor, PMI, and AE values. Overall description concluded that the metal oxide spinels are quite active and enormously applied in glycerol biorefinery in lab scale as well as industrial scale.
coredata.dc:title: Exploring the promotional effect of transition metals (Cr and V) on the catalytic activity of MgO for glycerol carbonate synthesis
